news.title: Popular movies are spreading misinformation about the reality of human trafficking
news.summary: Hollywood loves a good bad guy. From ruthless mobsters to drug kingpins to serial killers, evil characters are often plucked from real-world events.

facebook.title: Movies and myths about human trafficking
facebook.summary: It's not surprising that Hollywood gets it wrong when it comes to depicting human trafficking. The problem arises when policy decisions get influenced by what we see on screen.

facebook.title: Movies and myths about human trafficking
facebook.summary:
For some people "Taken" is their only knowledge of trafficking. In presentations I often say, "You are not Liam Neesen nor can you do what he did in the movie! No vigilanteism!"

Movies fail to convey the complexity and the atrocities. This article is by P

facebook.summary:

facebook.title: Movies and myths about human trafficking
facebook.summary: Popular movies are spreading misinformation about the reality of human trafficking. That’s a problem because only good information can help us end the practice.

facebook.title: Movies and myths about human trafficking
facebook.summary: Watched Liam Neeson take down criminal gangs, guns blazing, in 'Taken'? Hollywood will keep churning out action movies, so the least we can do is educate ourselves about the myths vs. realities of human trafficking. Get the facts here: ijm.org.au/how-we-wo

facebook.summary: While we're definitely seeing an improvement in the types of #humantrafficking cases represented in films, as well as, a stronger focus on support for survivors in policy initiatives, we want to #tbt to this article from January as a reminder to learn abou

facebook.title: Movies and myths about human trafficking
facebook.summary: Viewers of Hollywood films about human trafficking might also be misled into thinking that the problem is a foreign one, leaving them unaware of the role Americans play in human trafficking.
